title: Brenden Aaronson : Leeds , relegation , anti - U . S .  noise , Union Berlin and what next

For Aaronson, who joined Union on a season-long loan in the summer on the back of suffering relegation from the Premier League with Leeds United, it must feel like a never-ending cycle of misery.
In fact, the 23-year-old could be forgiven for saying heâ€™d rather not talk about any of it â€” whether that be Union Berlin, relegation with Leeds or losing matches.

More than anything, Aaronson talks about refusing to allow what has happened since moving to Leeds for Â£25million ($30.8m) from Red Bull Salzburg last year define him and about his determination to use the remainder of this season to turn things around at Union Berlin (who The Athletic has been embedded with this season) both for the club and for himself.

It is the second match of the Bundesliga season and Union are leading 1-0 when Aaronson is shown a second yellow card.
Despite playing with 10 men for 70 minutes, Union went on to win the game 4-1, but news of Aaronsonâ€™s dismissal (which seemed incredibly harsh) caused a stir on social media.

â€œBrenden Aaronson is a superbly skilled footballer and a young man who doesnâ€™t deserve any of the s*** being thrown at him here. Keep it to your own sites, please.â€

Aaronson looks across the room at Sweetman. â€œThanks for defending me,â€ he says, his voice quiet and sincere. â€œI appreciate that.â€
Social media can be a brutal place at times and it is easy to understand why Aaronson and so many other professional footballers these days choose to ignore what is posted on there. â€œAaronson has shown glimpses of skill and nobody behind the scenes at Leeds has anything but warm words for a young player who one staff member described as the â€˜ideal son-in-lawâ€™, adding that he stays after training every day to rehearse set pieces and finishing. The staff member added, however, that the emotional toll of the season has weighed heavily on his shoulders and he has, at times, overthought matters as confidence ebbed away from his play.â€

Aaronson listens to that extract, which is taken from an article that was published by The Athletic in May, when Leeds were on the brink of relegation from the Premier League and the post-mortem was already underway at Elland Road.
The â€œideal son-in-lawâ€ reference prompts Aaronson to chuckle. As for the wider sentiment, he nods in agreement.
â€œI would say thatâ€™s a fair quote,â€ Aaronson replies. â€œThe glimpses, I think, are true. I think I showed in the first half of the season why I was proud of the way I played. And I think everybody in my inner circle was thinking that I might have a little bit of a harder time getting used to the league. The first couple of games, I played really well and then I had some other good games in there, too.â€
Aaronson pauses for a moment. â€œAt the end, it was really tough, confidence-wise, to go out there. I didnâ€™t feel like I was playing my best. I feel like I was letting my team-mates down, I felt like I was letting the fanbase down at times.
â€œYouâ€™re thinking all the time. Youâ€™re not just playing. And I think when Iâ€™m playing my best is when Iâ€™m enjoying the game and Iâ€™m in a flow state. Thereâ€™s no thinking, thereâ€™s just playing and just doing what I feel and that creative side comes out when Iâ€™m in the flow.

When things were going wrong at Leeds, Aaronsonâ€™s response was to stay out after training and practise even harder. Another bag of footballs, another shooting session.

â€œYouâ€™re driving yourself crazy about scoring and assisting, then it starts to take over your mind and thatâ€™s all you care about,â€ Aaronson explains. â€œSo then the other things, like the (general) play, starts to go down because you want to score so bad, you wanna assist so bad.
â€œI remember talking to Jesse (Marsch, the former Leeds coach) about it. He was like, â€˜Youâ€™re putting way too much pressure on yourself. Youâ€™re so focused on it all the time, about scoring goals and getting assists, that youâ€™re not letting yourself just playâ€™.â€
Perhaps all of that is to be expected. Aaronson, after all, was only 21 years old when he signed for Leeds â€” for a fee that, he says, never bothered him, but arguably raised expectations among the fanbase to an unrealistic level.
Looking back, it was a chaotic season for Leeds full stop. The team was led by four different managers â€” Marsch, the then-under-23 coach Michael Skubala, Javi Gracia and Sam Allardyce â€” and Leeds registered only three Premier League victories after the season resumed in December following the World Cup in Qatar.

â€œIâ€™m proud to be an American and to represent my country in the World Cup is the biggest thing Iâ€™ve ever done in my life. To have my family name on the back, it was honestly a dream come true,â€ he says.
â€œBut when I look back, it feels like itâ€™s a fever dream because it just went by like this (clicks his fingers). And then Iâ€™m flying (out of Qatar), I had three days off after the World Cup and then I was back in Leeds, already getting ready for the next Prem game.â€
Last season was relentless in that respect. Aaronson started every Premier League game until Nottingham Forest away in February, when he somehow made the substitutesâ€™ bench despite spending the lead-up to the match in hospital with appendicitis.

â€œI was watching the (San Francisco) 49ers (on TV) because Iâ€™m a 49ers fan and just going to bed like a normal night and then all of a sudden I wake up and Iâ€™m rolling in pain because I have appendicitis,â€ he explains. â€œThe next thing I know, Iâ€™m going to the hospital and Iâ€™m in for three days. I came out of the hospital, trained one day and then was in the squad for the next game.â€
That desire to carry on playing is typical of Aaronson. Whatever criticism is thrown at him, he could never be accused of not trying his best â€” something his father ingrained in him from a young age, when Aaronson would return to pre-season with a demand to win the bleep test (a continuous running exercise that measures fitness levels).
A natural athlete, Aaronson covers a phenomenal amount of ground in matches, pressing and chasing down lost causes, as he demonstrated when he forced the Chelsea â€™keeper Edouard Mendy into a mistake early last season, leading to the midfielderâ€™s only goal for Leeds.
But there were questions around other aspects of Aaronsonâ€™s game at Leeds, in particular his physicality and whether he was strong enough to play in the Premier League.

Instead, he responds candidly when asked what he thinks about the idea that, physically, it may have been too big an adjustment to expect him to go straight from the Austrian Bundesliga to the intensity of playing every week in the Premier League.

Relegation was a collective failure at Leeds â€” the owners, board, coaches and players all have to take some level of responsibility â€” but every person will have dealt with the experience in their own way.
For Aaronson, who had come from a totally different culture at Salzburg and Philadelphia, last season sounds like it was a shock to the system.
â€œI think going through something like that and being as young asâ€¦ I mean, Iâ€™ve never been in a situation like that in my life. I came from Philadelphia Union, then I was in Salzburg; we won everything in Salzburg. I was never used to losing. Even in my MLS career, we were always winning.

â€œBut I think that at the end of the season when you get relegatedâ€¦ you just feel like youâ€™ve let a lot of people down.â€
There were three scenarios for Aaronson in the summer: stay with Leeds in the Championship, go out on loan or move permanently.
A clause in Aaronsonâ€™s contract â€” and he was one of many players at Leeds in this position â€” enabled him to join another club on loan provided his salary was covered in full.
Union Berlin, who had finished fourth in the Bundesliga and qualified for the Champions League for the first time in their history, were quick to show interest â€” at a time when Leeds were without a coach and going through a period of upheaval behind the scenes. â€œI felt like this was the best decision that I could make â€” playing in the Bundesliga and playing in the Champions League â€” to help my career and get me better. So thatâ€™s why I made the decision.â€
Aaronsonâ€™s affection for Leeds comes across as genuine. From his point of view, there is no friction or ill-feeling because of how last season played out. Aaronson, in short, was focused solely on what happened on the pitch at Leeds and nothing has changed now. He is still in touch with his former team-mates and delighted to see that Leeds, who are third in the Championship, are on the up again.
â€œI try to stay in contact with all of the players as best I can,â€ he says. â€œI texted Cry (Crysencio Summerville) the other day for his birthday. I donâ€™t have any bitter thoughts or anything like that because I just pride myself on being as positive as I can and rooting for my friends and the team I played for last year. Unfortunately, itâ€™s a different story at Union. A landmark season that promised so much has unravelled in a way that nobody could have imagined.
